properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hazardous winter conditions is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 70 km/h. Time span: Christmas Eve morning until Boxing Day. Locations: Grand Falls-Windsor to the Baie Verte Peninsula. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will begin Christmas Eve morning and continue into Christmas Eve night. Gusty northeasterly winds will also develop on Christmas Eve and strengthen to strong northwesterlies with gusts to 70 km/h overnight Christmas Eve night. Snow will become lighter and more intermittent for Christmas Day and Boxing Day, but the strong northwesterly winds will persist, resulting in poor visibility in blowing snow. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-24T11:06:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-23T19:07:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3150166443.2019
Area: Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm. Locations: western and southern Newfoundland. Time span: Monday night into Christmas Eve. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin over southwestern Newfoundland this evening and spread across most of Newfoundland by early on Tuesday. Snow is expected to taper to flurries by early on Christmas Day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-24T00:52:07-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Very large waves, pounding surf and elevated sea water levels are expected later this week. Wave heights: 7 to 9 metres, breaking upon approach to shore. Locations: east and northeast coasts of Newfoundland. Time span: Thursday and Friday. Remarks: a prolonged period of strong winds will cause very large waves to build later this week. Storm surge and coastal flooding may occur along shorelines exposed to the north and northeast, especially near the high tides. The highest water levels are expected to occur on Friday morning, but vulnerable areas may become susceptible to flooding as early as the Thursday morning high tide. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-24T11:17:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-23T19:18:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2074079996.2019

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A prolonged period of hazardous winter conditions is expected. Total snowfall: 30 to 40 cm. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h. Time span: Christmas Eve morning until Boxing Day night. Locations: Gander and northeastern Newfoundland. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will begin Christmas Eve morning and continue into Christmas Eve night. The snow will become lighter and more intermittent on Christmas Day, before a second round of heavier snow sets in by the morning of Boxing Day. Gusty northeasterly winds will develop on Christmas Eve and strengthen to strong northwesterlies with gusts to 80 km/h overnight Christmas Eve night. The strong northwesterlies will then persist through Boxing Day. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-24T11:07:20-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-23T19:08:20-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1341873310.2019
Area: Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snow Squall Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Persistent snow squalls are expected to develop. Under the snow squall bands, visibilities will be significantly reduced due to the heavy snow combined with blowing snow, and snow will quickly accumulate. Snow squalls are likely to develop on Tuesday. Total snowfall: locally 15 to 25 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 60 to 80 km/h. Locations: western Cape Breton. Time span: Tuesday and Tuesday night. Remarks: Flurries will develop on Tuesday, with areas of snow squall activity likely as cold northwesterly winds strengthen. ### Travel may be hazardous due to sudden changes in the weather. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snow squall watches are issued when conditions are favourable for the formation of bands of snow that could produce intense accumulating snow or near zero visibilities. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-24T11:29:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-23T19:30:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2163929065.2019
Area: Inverness County - Mabou and north, Victoria County

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 25 cm is expected. Locations: southern Avalon Peninsula. Time span: early Christmas Eve morning until late Christmas Eve night. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will begin early in the morning on Christmas Eve and continue until into Christmas Eve night. The snow may also mix with rain at times over extreme southern areas. In addition, strong northwesterly winds will develop on Christmas Eve night resulting in areas of blowing snow. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong arctic ridge of high pressure across northern Yukon is giving temperatures near minus 44C. Light winds at times will result in wind chill values in the minus 50's. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather in British Columbia or Yukon, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm or #YTStorm.
Expires: 2019-12-24T12:08:57-00:00

Area: Old Crow
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Heavy snowfall with blowing snow is expected. Total snowfall: 20 to 35 cm by Christmas Day morning. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 80 km/h. Time span: Christmas Eve morning until late Christmas Eve night. Remarks: Snow, at times heavy, will begin Christmas Eve morning and continue much of Christmas Eve night. Strong easterly winds gusting to 60 km/h will develop during the afternoon on Christmas Eve and further increase to strong northwesterlies gusting to 80 km/h Christmas Eve night. While the snow will ease late Christmas Eve night, strong northwesterly winds will persist through Christmas Day and Boxing Day, causing blowing snow at times. In addition, a second round of steadier snow, possibly heavy, is expected to develop by afternoon on Boxing Day. Further details on accumulations for this period will be provided as more information becomes available. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Visibility will be suddenly reduced to near zero at times in heavy snow and blowing snow. Winter storm warnings are issued when multiple types of severe winter weather are expected to occur together. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2019-12-24T11:09:16-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2019-12-23T19:10:16-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3829464174.2019
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, St. John's and vicinity, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of about 15 cm is expected. Locations: Avalon Peninsula. Time span: early Christmas Eve morning until early Christmas morning. Remarks: The heaviest snow is expected to begin on Christmas Eve morning and continue until early on Christmas Day. Winds are expected to increase through the night on Tuesday night and will remain high on Christmas Day. The fresh snowfall and strong winds could combine to cause reduced visibilities in blowing snow especially over exposed areas. ### Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.

properties.Title: Special Air Quality Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Elevated pollution levels are expected or occurring. Air quality advisory in effect for Vanderhoof. The Ministry of Environment and Climate Change Strategy in collaboration with Northern Health has issued an Air Quality Advisory for Vanderhoof because of high concentrations of particulate matter. Real-time air quality observations can be found at https://www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air ### For more information on current air quality, visit www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/environment/air-land-water/air. Visit www.airhealth.ca for information on how to reduce your health risk and your personal contribution to pollution levels, as well as for current and forecast AQHI values. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2019-12-24T06:24:27-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 20 cm with more possible. Locations: northeastern and eastern Newfoundland. Maximum wind gusts: northwesterly 60 to 80 km/h on Christmas Day. Time span: tonight, Christmas Eve and Christmas Day. Remarks: Snow is expected to begin to begin Christmas Eve morning and continue into Christmas Eve night. Snow is expected to become more intermittent on Christmas Day, but northwesterly winds are expected to increase to strong by early on Christmas Day. Fresh snow and strong winds will make for poor driving conditions for Christmas Day. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
